entry.title: Poking at POSIX message queues
entry.summary:
Poking around at POSIX message queues in Linux¶

I was recently reviewing some code introduced usage of POSIX message queues into some tests. I hadn't used them before, and nothing in the code base already used them, so I needed to familiarize myself with them a bit.

One annoyance of working with POSIX message queues on Linux is that there doesn't seem to be a ubiquitous command-line tool for manipulating them. Their predecessor, sys v message queues, have ipcmk

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Poking-around-at-POSIX-message-queues-in-Linux">Poking around at POSIX message queues in Linux<a class="anchor-link" href="#Poking-around-at-POSIX-message-queues-in-Linux">¶</a></h1><p>I was recently reviewing some code introduced usage of POSIX message queues into some tests. I hadn't used them before, and nothing in the code base already used them, so I needed to familiarize myself with them a bit.</p>
<p>One annoyance of working with POSIX message queues on Linux is that there doesn't seem to be a ubiquitous command-line tool for manipulating them. Their predecessor, sys v message queues, have <a href="https://linux.die.net/man/1/ipcmk"><code>ipcmk</code></a>, <a href="https://linux.die.net/man/1/ipcrm"><code>ipcrm</code></a>, and <a href="https://linux.die.net/man/1/ipcs"><code>ipcs</code></a>. <a href="https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/71045">Apparently</a> HP-UX has an analagous tool <code>pipcs</code>, but it hasn't been ported to other platforms.</p>
<p>This is somewhat mitigated by the ability to mount a virtual filesystem representing the message queues on the system, and manipulate them through normal file commands. You must be root to mount the system, but then any user can then use it. <a href="https://linux.die.net/man/7/mq_overview"><code>mq_overview(7)</code></a> has details, with an example of mounting to <code>/dev/mqueue</code>. On my system (Ubuntu 18.04), this system appears to be automatically mounted. It's unclear though whether or where you can count on it to already be mounted on other systems.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Creating-a-queue">Creating a queue<a class="anchor-link" href="#Creating-a-queue">¶</a></h2><p>We can create a queue using normal file system APIs. Let's use <code>mktemp</code> to generate a unique name for this example:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">QFILE</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="sb">`</span>mktemp /dev/mqueue/mqtest.XXXX<span class="sb">`</span>
<span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="nv">$QFILE</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>/dev/mqueue/mqtest.OBmQ
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Examining-a-queue">Examining a queue<a class="anchor-link" href="#Examining-a-queue">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can <code>ls</code> it, though this doesn't tell us much:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>ls -l <span class="nv">$QFILE</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>-rw------- 1 jnewsome jnewsome 80 May 11 08:49 /dev/mqueue/mqtest.OBmQ
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can <code>cat</code> it, giving some metadata about the state of the queue:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>cat <span class="nv">$QFILE</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>QSIZE:0          NOTIFY:0     SIGNO:0     NOTIFY_PID:0     
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To get more information, we'll need to use the C api.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The C APIs take a queue name, not the the file system path. The queue name is the basename of the path, with a leading <code>/</code>:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">QNAME</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"/</span><span class="k">$(</span>basename <span class="nv">$QFILE</span><span class="k">)</span><span class="s2">"</span>
<span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>/mqtest.OBmQ
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's write a small shell function to compile our test programs. It'll take the program source from <code>stdin</code>:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>compile <span class="o">()</span> <span class="o">{</span>
  gcc -o <span class="nv">$1</span> -xc -Wall -Werror - -lrt
<span class="o">}</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Our helper programs are going to have a common preamble. Let's stick those in a shell variable:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">read</span> -r -d <span class="s1">''</span> C_PRELIMINARIES <span class="s"><< EOM</span>
<span class="s">#include <fcntl.h></span>
<span class="s">#include <sys/stat.h></span>
<span class="s">#include <mqueue.h></span>
<span class="s">#include <stdio.h></span>
<span class="s">#include <stdlib.h></span>

<span class="s">#define CHECK(x) { \</span>
<span class="s">  if (!(x)) {\</span>
<span class="s">    perror(#x);\</span>
<span class="s">    exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\</span>
<span class="s">  }\</span>
<span class="s">}</span>

<span class="s">#define CHECK_GTE0(x) CHECK((x) >= 0)</span>
<span class="s">#define CHECK_EQ0(x) CHECK((x) == 0)</span>

<span class="s">EOM</span>
<span class="nb">true</span> <span class="c1"># Suppress error</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now let's write and compile our <code>mq_getattr</code> program:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>compile mq_getattr <span class="s"><<EOF</span>
<span class="s">$C_PRELIMINARIES</span>

<span class="s">int main(int argc, char **argv) {</span>
<span class="s">  mqd_t q;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_GTE0(q = mq_open(argv[1], O_RDONLY));</span>
<span class="s">  struct mq_attr attr;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_EQ0(mq_getattr(q, &attr));</span>
<span class="s">  printf("flags: %ld\n", attr.mq_flags);</span>
<span class="s">  printf("maxmsg: %ld\n", attr.mq_maxmsg);</span>
<span class="s">  printf("msgsize: %ld\n", attr.mq_msgsize);</span>
<span class="s">  printf("curmsgs: %ld\n", attr.mq_curmsgs);</span>
<span class="s">}</span>
<span class="s">EOF</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Running it gives us some new information about the queue:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_getattr <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>flags: 0
maxmsg: 10
msgsize: 8192
curmsgs: 0
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Writing-to-the-queue">Writing to the queue<a class="anchor-link" href="#Writing-to-the-queue">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Unfortunately there doesn't seem to be a way to write messages to the queue via the file system API. At least, attempting to do so in the obvious way fails:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="s2">"A message"</span> > <span class="nv">$QFILE</span> <span class="o">||</span> <span class="nb">true</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>bash: echo: write error: Invalid argument
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's write another small program that'll read up to the maximum message length from <code>stdin</code>, and then write it to the queue with a specified priority:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>compile mq_send <span class="s"><<EOF</span>
<span class="s">$C_PRELIMINARIES</span>

<span class="s">int main(int argc, char **argv) {</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK(argc == 3);</span>
<span class="s">  const char* qname = argv[1];</span>
<span class="s">  unsigned int priority = atoi(argv[2]);</span>
<span class="s">  </span>
<span class="s">  mqd_t q;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_GTE0(q = mq_open(qname, O_WRONLY));</span>
<span class="s">  struct mq_attr attr;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_EQ0(mq_getattr(q, &attr));</span>
<span class="s">  </span>
<span class="s">  char *buf = malloc(attr.mq_msgsize);</span>
<span class="s">  size_t n;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_GTE0(n = fread(buf, 1, attr.mq_msgsize, stdin));</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_GTE0(mq_send(q, buf, n, priority));</span>
<span class="s">}</span>
<span class="s">EOF</span>
<span class="nb">true</span> <span class="c1"># Suppress error</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>...and use it to write a message to the queue:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_send <span class="nv">$QNAME</span> <span class="m">0</span> <span class="s"><<EOF</span>
<span class="s">Hello message queue</span>
<span class="s">Second line</span>
<span class="s">EOF</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Examining the queue, we can see that there's a message there:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>cat <span class="nv">$QFILE</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>QSIZE:32         NOTIFY:0     SIGNO:0     NOTIFY_PID:0     
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_getattr <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>flags: 0
maxmsg: 10
msgsize: 8192
curmsgs: 1
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Reading-from-the-queue">Reading from the queue<a class="anchor-link" href="#Reading-from-the-queue">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Again, we'll need to write a program to read from the queue. This one will just cat the first message in the queue to <code>stdout</code>, blocking if there isn't a message there yet:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [14]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>compile mq_recv <span class="s"><<EOF</span>
<span class="s">$C_PRELIMINARIES</span>

<span class="s">int main(int argc, char **argv) {</span>
<span class="s">  mqd_t q;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_GTE0(q = mq_open(argv[1], O_RDONLY));</span>
<span class="s">  struct mq_attr attr;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_EQ0(mq_getattr(q, &attr));</span>
<span class="s">  </span>
<span class="s">  char *buf = malloc(attr.mq_msgsize);</span>
<span class="s">  ssize_t n;</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_GTE0(n = mq_receive(q, buf, attr.mq_msgsize, NULL));</span>
<span class="s">  CHECK_GTE0(fwrite(buf, 1, n, stdout));</span>
<span class="s">}</span>
<span class="s">EOF</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As expected, we can read out the message we wrote to the queue above:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [15]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_recv <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Hello message queue
Second line
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>...and doing so returns the queue to its empty state:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>cat <span class="nv">$QFILE</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>QSIZE:0          NOTIFY:0     SIGNO:0     NOTIFY_PID:0     
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_getattr <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>flags: 0
maxmsg: 10
msgsize: 8192
curmsgs: 0
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Multiple-messages">Multiple messages<a class="anchor-link" href="#Multiple-messages">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can write two messages to the queue and get them back individually:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_send <span class="nv">$QNAME</span> <span class="m">0</span> <span class="s"><<EOF</span>
<span class="s">First message first line</span>
<span class="s">First message second line</span>
<span class="s">EOF</span>
./mq_send <span class="nv">$QNAME</span> <span class="m">0</span> <span class="s"><<EOF</span>
<span class="s">Second message first line</span>
<span class="s">Second message second line</span>
<span class="s">EOF</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_recv <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>First message first line
First message second line
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./mq_recv <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Second message first line
Second message second line
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can use priorities to get them back in a different order. We didn't talk about priorities earlier, but that's the integer passed on the command-line after the queue name. When reading from a queue, the earliest message with the highest priority is returned:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="s2">"First message, priority 0"</span> <span class="p">|</span> ./mq_send <span class="nv">$QNAME</span> <span class="m">0</span>
<span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="s2">"Second message, priority 0"</span> <span class="p">|</span> ./mq_send <span class="nv">$QNAME</span> <span class="m">0</span>
<span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="s2">"Third message, priority 1"</span> <span class="p">|</span> ./mq_send <span class="nv">$QNAME</span> <span class="m">1</span>
<span class="nb">echo</span> <span class="s2">"Fourth message, priority 1"</span> <span class="p">|</span> ./mq_send <span class="nv">$QNAME</span> <span class="m">1</span>
./mq_recv <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
./mq_recv <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
./mq_recv <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
./mq_recv <span class="nv">$QNAME</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Third message, priority 1
Fourth message, priority 1
First message, priority 0
Second message, priority 0
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Resource-usage-and-cleanup">Resource usage and cleanup<a class="anchor-link" href="#Resource-usage-and-cleanup">¶</a></h2><p>There are system-wide and per-user limits on message queues, and these are surprisingly small by default. Let's go ahead and clean up our queue from above:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>rm <span class="nv">$QFILE</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>While writing this I inadvertently bumped into the per-user limit when I was unable to create a 10th queue:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [23]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="k">for</span> i in <span class="o">{</span><span class="m">1</span>..10<span class="o">}</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="k">do</span> touch /dev/mqueue/exhaust<span class="si">${</span><span class="nv">i</span><span class="si">}</span><span class="p">;</span> <span class="k">done</span>
<span class="nb">true</span> <span class="c1"># Suppress error</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>touch: cannot touch '/dev/mqueue/exhaust10': Too many open files
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I believe the limit we're hitting is the per-user limit on message queues in bytes:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [24]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">ulimit</span> -a <span class="p">|</span> grep POSIX
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>POSIX message queues     (bytes, -q) 819200
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As we saw from the <code>mq_getattr</code> output above, each queue has <code>msgsize</code> of <code>8192</code>, and <code>maxmsg</code> of <code>10</code>. Therefore <code>10</code> queues would equal the <code>819200</code> limit. Apparently the limit is applied to the <em>potential</em> size of the queue. This is probably preferable over being able to create more queues and then hitting the resource limit when trying to write to them.</p>
<p>It does seem likely that these parametes were chosen with the intent of allowing <code>10</code> queues per user, but that either the limit is being applied with <code><</code> rather than <code><=</code>, or that there's some other per-queue overhead is also being counted.</p>
<p>In any case, let's clean up.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>rm /dev/mqueue/exhaust*
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
 

</body>

Interposing internal libc calls¶

TLDR¶

Calls within libc are generally pre-linked. As a result, they can't be interposed using LD_PRELOAD. This makes it tricky to use LD_PRELOAD to intercept, e.g., all calls to write, but there are some workarounds.

Doubling all writes to standard output¶

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Interposing-internal-libc-calls">Interposing internal libc calls<a class="anchor-link" href="#Interposing-internal-libc-calls">¶</a></h1><h2 id="TLDR">TLDR<a class="anchor-link" href="#TLDR">¶</a></h2><p>Calls within libc are generally pre-linked. As a result, they can't be interposed using <code>LD_PRELOAD</code>. This makes it tricky to use <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> to intercept, e.g., all calls to <code>write</code>, but there are some workarounds.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Doubling-all-writes-to-standard-output">Doubling all writes to standard output<a class="anchor-link" href="#Doubling-all-writes-to-standard-output">¶</a></h2><p>Suppose we want to use <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> to force any output to <code>stdout</code> to happen twice. We'll start with a simple program that writes to <code>stdout</code> once:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>cat ./call_write.c
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>#include <unistd.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc, char **argv) {
    const char *msg = "Hello write\n";
    write(STDOUT_FILENO, msg, strlen(msg));
    return 0;
}
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>When we run <code>./call_write</code> we get the expected output:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [26]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>./call_write
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Hello write
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>If we examine the compiled binary, we can see that the call is made through the PLT (Procedure Linkage Table):</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [28]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>objdump -D call_write <span class="p">|</span> grep <span class="s1">'call.*write'</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>call_write:     file format elf64-x86-64
  400567:	e8 a4 fe ff ff       	callq  400410 <write@plt>
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This means that at run-time, the dynamic linker is responsible for finding the address of <code>write</code> and patching it into the PLT. This <code>call</code> instruction will then use the patched table to call the correct function. We can enable debugging-output in the dynamic linker to see that it resolves the <code>write</code> symbol to libc, as expected:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">LD_DEBUG</span><span class="o">=</span>bindings ./call_write <span class="m">2</span>><span class="p">&</span><span class="m">1</span> <span class="p">|</span> grep <span class="s1">'symbol.*write'</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>     11280:	binding file ./call_write [0] to /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 [0]: normal symbol `write' [GLIBC_2.2.5]
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Interposing-a-direct-call-to-write-works">Interposing a direct call to write works<a class="anchor-link" href="#Interposing-a-direct-call-to-write-works">¶</a></h3><p>We can <em>interpose</em> this call to <code>write</code> by using the <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> environment variable to tell the dynamic linker to try resolving symbols in <em>our</em> library that we provide before any other libraries.</p>
<p>Let's create a small library with our own implementation of <code>write</code>. We'll simply get the symbol for libc's <code>write</code>, and then call it twice.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [31]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>cat interpose_write.c
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>#define _GNU_SOURCE

#include <dlfcn.h>
#include <unistd.h>

ssize_t write(int fd, const void *buf, size_t count) {
    // Look up the next `write` symbol, which will be glibc's
    ssize_t (*orig_write)(int fd, const void *buf, size_t count) = 
        dlsym(RTLD_NEXT, "write");
    if (STDOUT_FILENO) {
        // If we're writing to stdout, call the original function an extra time.
        orig_write(fd, buf, count);
    }
    return orig_write(fd, buf, count);
}
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Using <code>LD_PRELOAD</code>, this works as expected. The call to <code>write</code> from our <code>call_fwrite</code> program is intercepted, and we see the output twice:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [32]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">LD_PRELOAD</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nv">$PWD</span>/interpose_write.so ./call_write
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Hello write
Hello write
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can also examine the dynamic linker's debug output again to see that it resolves <code>write</code> twice. First when patching the PLT it finds our <code>write</code>. At run-time when we ask it for the "next" <code>write</code>, it finds libc's version:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [35]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">LD_DEBUG</span><span class="o">=</span>bindings <span class="nv">LD_PRELOAD</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nv">$PWD</span>/interpose_write.so ./call_write <span class="m">2</span>><span class="p">&</span><span class="m">1</span> <span class="p">|</span> grep <span class="s1">'symbol.*write'</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>     11297:	binding file ./call_write [0] to /home/jnewsome/projects/dev-journal/interposing-fwrite/interposing-fwrite/interpose_write.so [0]: normal symbol `write' [GLIBC_2.2.5]
     11297:	binding file /home/jnewsome/projects/dev-journal/interposing-fwrite/interposing-fwrite/interpose_write.so [0] to /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 [0]: normal symbol `write'
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Interposing-all-the-writes">Interposing <em>all</em> the writes<a class="anchor-link" href="#Interposing-all-the-writes">¶</a></h2><p>So far so good. What happens though if the program we're interposing calls some other libc function to write to standard output? They'll all end up eventually needing to make a <code>write</code> system call, so our wrapper should still work... right?</p>
<p>Let's see what happens if the program calls <code>fwrite</code> instead of <code>write</code>:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [36]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>cat call_fwrite.c
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc, char **argv) {
    const char *msg = "Hello fwrite\n";
    fwrite(msg, 1, strlen(msg), stdout);
    return 0;
}
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [37]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">LD_PRELOAD</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nv">$PWD</span>/interpose_write.so ./call_fwrite
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Hello fwrite
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It didn't work. To find out why, let's look at calls to <code>write</code> from within libc:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>objdump -D /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 <span class="p">|</span> grep <span class="s1">'call.*__write@@'</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>   21cc5:	e8 76 e4 0e 00       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
   303ab:	e8 90 fd 0d 00       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
   7c79a:	e8 41 3a 09 00       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
   8b1b8:	e8 83 4f 08 00       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
   8b1e0:	e8 fb 4f 08 00       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
  1154af:	e8 8c ac ff ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  1175bd:	e8 1e 8c ff ff       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
  121ae3:	e8 58 e6 fe ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  123965:	e8 76 c8 fe ff       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
  124059:	e8 82 c1 fe ff       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
  13aae4:	e8 57 56 fd ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  13aca3:	e8 98 54 fd ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  13adc2:	e8 79 53 fd ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  13b840:	e8 fb 48 fd ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  13b982:	e8 b9 47 fd ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  13ba04:	e8 37 47 fd ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  14e7ec:	e8 4f 19 fc ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  156365:	e8 d6 9d fb ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  15aa25:	e8 16 57 fb ff       	callq  110140 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5>
  163c6e:	e8 6d c5 fa ff       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
  164884:	e8 57 b9 fa ff       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
  164a51:	e8 8a b7 fa ff       	callq  1101e0 <__write@@GLIBC_2.2.5+0xa0>
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It turns out that none of the internal calls to <code>write</code> actually use the <code>write</code> symbol. They use <code>__write</code>, which is an alias:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">__write_address</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="sb">`</span>nm -D /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 <span class="p">|</span> awk <span class="s1">'/__write/ {print $1}'</span><span class="sb">`</span>
nm -D /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 <span class="p">|</span> grep <span class="nv">$__write_address</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>0000000000110140 W write
0000000000110140 W __write
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Unfortunately, simply overriding <code>__write</code> doesn't work either:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>cat interpose_underbar_write.c
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>#define _GNU_SOURCE

#include <dlfcn.h>
#include <unistd.h>

ssize_t __write(int fd, const void *buf, size_t count) {
    ssize_t (*orig_write)(int fd, const void *buf, size_t count) = 
        dlsym(RTLD_NEXT, "__write");
    orig_write(fd, buf, count);
    return orig_write(fd, buf, count);
}
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">LD_PRELOAD</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nv">$PWD</span>/interpose_underbar_write.so ./call_fwrite
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Hello fwrite
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Note that in the <code>call</code> instructions above, the symbols don't have the <code>@plt</code> suffix. The real issue is that none of these calls are via the PLT. When glibc itself is built and linked, the linker can see the call sites and intended destinations at the same time, so it can and does link them at that time. The <em>dynamic</em> linker isn't involved, so <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> has no effect on these call sites.</p>
<p>Looking at the dynamic linker's debug output again, we can see it never looks up <code>write</code> or <code>__write</code> at all; only <code>fwrite</code>:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [38]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span><span class="nv">LD_DEBUG</span><span class="o">=</span>bindings <span class="nv">LD_PRELOAD</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="nv">$PWD</span>/interpose_underbar_write.so ./call_fwrite <span class="m">2</span>><span class="p">&</span><span class="m">1</span> <span class="p">|</span> grep <span class="s1">'symbol.*write'</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>     11317:	binding file ./call_fwrite [0] to /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 [0]: normal symbol `fwrite' [GLIBC_2.2.5]
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Can-we-interpose-some-other-function?">Can we interpose some other function?<a class="anchor-link" href="#Can-we-interpose-some-other-function?">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Using <code>strace</code>, we can get the call stack when the <code>write</code> system call is made. Maybe we can interpose one of these other functions?</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-bash"><pre><span></span>strace -k -e write ./call_fwrite <span class="m">2</span>><span class="p">&</span><span class="m">1</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>

<p>There are a few way around this.</p>
<ul>
<li>Interpose every entry point into glibc that could end up calling the functionality we want to modify. This could work, but developing and maintaining 100% coverage is difficult and fragile. We'd also end up having to reimplement parts of libc. e.g. if we write a wrapper for <code>fwrite</code>, and want to interpose on the individual <code>write</code> system calls, we'd have to reimplement the in-memory buffering that <code>fwrite</code> puts in between the two ourselves (or forgo it).</li>
<li>Patch glibc to make calls via the PLT, so that we can interpose them via <code>LD_PRELOAD</code>. We could then inject our custom glibc as another <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> library as done <a href="../patching-libc-to-interpose-syscalls">here</a>. This seems like a promising shortcut, but could result in subtle issues if our patched glibc isn't binary-compatible with the headers that the target code was compiled against; e.g. uses different data type or constant definitions. We should be able to prevent those difficulties by being very careful to build our libc consistently with our distribution's libc, but we'd need to do so for every platform we intend to run on.</li>
<li>Use a different interposition mechanism than <code>LD_PRELOAD</code>. In particular, <code>ptrace</code> tells the OS kernel to intercept the system calls themselves, ensuring that we see every system call regardless of what function it's coming from, whether the program is statically linked, or even if the <code>syscall</code> instructions themselves are inlined. This works best when the behavior we're trying to modify is at the syscall level. It's a bit more work to implement, though. It may also have different performance characteristics, especially if there are other syscalls we're <em>not</em> interested in intercepting. We also can't attach a debugger to a program that is already being <code>ptrace</code>'d, making debugging more difficult.</li>
</ul>

entry.content:
Patching glibc to make its syscalls interposable

Suppose we have a program, call_write.c, that writes some strings to stdout:

$ cat ./call_write.c
#define _GNU_SOURCE

#include <unistd.h>
#include <sys/syscall.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc, char **argv) {
    const char* msg = "syscall\n";
    syscall(SYS_write, STDOUT_FILENO, msg, strlen(msg));

    msg = "write\n";
    write(STDOUT_FILENO, msg, strlen(msg));

    msg = "fwrite\n";
    fwrite(msg, 1, strlen(msg), stdout);

    printf("printf\n");
    fprintf(stdout, "fprintf\n");
    puts("puts");
    fputs("fputs\n", stdout);
    putc('!', stdout);
    putc('\n', stdout);
}

Output of call_write:

$ ./call_write
syscall
write
fwrite
printf
fprintf
puts
fputs
!

Suppose we want to double all output to stdout. All of the functions in call_write ultimately make a write syscall, so we interpose the syscall function directly.

$ cat ./interpose.c
#define _GNU_SOURCE

#include <stdarg.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <sys/syscall.h>
#include <stdio.h>

static long real_syscall(long n, long arg1, long arg2, long arg3, long arg4,
                         long arg5, long arg6) {
    long rv;
    asm volatile(
        "movq %[n], %%rax\n"
        "movq %[arg1], %%rdi\n"
        "movq %[arg2], %%rsi\n"
        "movq %[arg3], %%rdx\n"
        "movq %[arg4], %%r10\n"
        "movq %[arg5], %%r8\n"
        "movq %[arg6], %%r9\n"
        "syscall\n"
        "movq %%rax, %[rv]\n"
        : /* output parameters*/
        [rv] "=rm"(rv)
        : /* input parameters */
        [n] "rm"(n), [arg1] "rm"(arg1), [arg2] "rm"(arg2), [arg3] "rm"(arg3),
        [arg4] "rm"(arg4), [arg5] "rm"(arg5), [arg6] "rm"(arg6)
        : /* other clobbered regs */
        "rdi",
        // "SYSCALL also saves RFLAGS into R11"
        "r11",
        // "The SYSCALL instruction does not save the stack pointer (RSP)"
        "rsp",
        // Used to save rip; unclear whether it gets restored"
        "rcx",
        // Flags
        "cc",
        // Memory
        "memory");
    return rv;
}

long syscall(long n, ...) {
    va_list args;
    va_start(args, n);
    long arg1 = va_arg(args, long);
    long arg2 = va_arg(args, long);
    long arg3 = va_arg(args, long);
    long arg4 = va_arg(args, long);
    long arg5 = va_arg(args, long);
    long arg6 = va_arg(args, long);
    va_end(args);

    if (n == SYS_write && arg1 == STDOUT_FILENO) {
        real_syscall(n, arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4, arg5, arg6);
    }
    return real_syscall(n, arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4, arg5, arg6);
}

Unfortunately, it turns out that the libc implementations of these functions make inlined syscalls, so this only successfully interposes on and doubles the actual call to syscall:

$ LD_PRELOAD=$PWD/libinterpose.so ./call_write
syscall
syscall
write
fwrite
printf
fprintf
puts
fputs
!

We can fix this by using a patched libc that replaces inlined syscalls with calls to the syscall function, and also LD_PRELOAD'ing that. It turns out we primarily just need to redefine some syscall macros. When using the library as an LD_PRELOAD I initially got some crashes in code that tries to do a dynamic symbol lookup to determine whether it's not the primary libc in use; I worked around by effectively hard-coding the answer to "yes"

$ LD_PRELOAD=$PWD/libinterpose.so:$PWD/glibc-build/libc.so ./call_write
syscall
syscall
write
write
fwrite
printf
fprintf
puts
fputs
!
fwrite
printf
fprintf
puts
fputs
!

You may wonder why we don''t see the two, e.g. fwrite outputs directly next to each-other. This is because the functions that operate on the stdout FILE* stream, rather than directly on its file descriptor, write to an in-memory buffer. i.e. the corresponding writes get batched into a single write syscall.

Caveats

We'll run into subtle errors if our preloaded libc uses different data type or constant definitions than the libc against which the target program was compiled. Hopefully using the same implementation of libc (glibc, in this case), with a "close enough" version is sufficient. To be really sure though we'd need to patch the source of our distribution's libc, which may itself be patched, and be sure to use the same configuration and toolchain that our distribution used when building the libc it uses and distributes.

The workaround for avoiding the extra dynamic symbol lookups essentially tells glibc to always use mmap instead of brk for allocating memory. This will have some performance impact. Since the system's glibc shouldn't end up getting used at all, we might be able to hard-code the opposite default itself and tell it to ahead and use brk. For this proof-of-concept I just went with the more conservative approach.

I wouldn't be terribly surprised if we run into other issues at runtime similar to those dynamic symbol lookup crashes. glibc wasn't designed to be used in quite this way.

entry.content:
I got an interesting request a few months ago--to implement the telephony back-end for a real life dancing game to be played at the 2013 Three Rivers Arts Festival.

Dance Ave is a physical game where players try to reach all of several stations positioned around an area. Players may only move between stations by dancing with passers-by. The telephony back-end comes in at the stations, where players dial a special code with their cell phone. Doing so gives the player credit for reaching that station, tells them how many stations they have left to visit, and then plays the song for that station. Players use that song to groove over to the next station.

I ended up implementing the back-end with the Django web framework, and using the Tropo programmable telephony service. The more mainstream option for telephony of course would have been Twilio. I ended up using Tropo because initially we were also going to make an SMS-based game, and Tropo has cheaper rates for SMS. Still, Tropo was fairly pleasant to use. One nice feature in particular is that until you move your app from "debug mode" to "production mode", all services are free. So, you can feel free to blast the service with requests during development and testing without worrying about racking up a big bill.

Unfortunately the player scores were inadvertently reset both times the game was played. After reviewing the logs again, I found a usability issue with the administrative dashboard page that was most likely the cause. Long story short--from now on I'll remember to use the Post-Redirect-Get pattern to avoid accidental re-POSTs.

Luckily the score for Dance Ave is mostly immaterial, and folks still had fun playing it. The code is now available on GitHub.

entry.content:
Introduction

Two popular places to keep documentation for programming projects are:

  1. In README files in the code repository.
  2. In a separate wiki.

In this article, I propose that a compelling way to manage documentation is to combine the two: to write the documentation as markdown files in the code repository itself, and to publish those pages in a wiki-like format.

I also share my experience doing this on a SourceForge-hosted project, where it is already quite straight-forward to do this, and could be made even more convenient with only a few minor tweaks to SourceForge's Allura platform.

Why Markdown?

Markdown, as defined by its inventor Mark Gruber:

Markdown is two things: (1) a plain text formatting syntax; and (2) a software tool, written in Perl, that converts the plain text formatting to HTML.

There are other plain text formatting syntaxes and tools, but Markdown seems to have the most momentum, perhaps because of its natural-looking syntax. Since its inception, many tools have been created to parse Markdown files and convert them to formats suitable for publishing, such as html and pdf. (One of my favorites is pandoc, which also adds some useful extensions).

There are many tools for publishing a whole site or wiki from Markdown-generated files, and several project-hosting platforms include support for Markdown-based wikis and for rendering in-repository Markdown files, including SourceForge's Allura platform.

Why In-Repository?

The software engineering principle of Don't Repeat Yourself applies equally well to documentation. There should be only one canonical place for documentation. Having documentation in two places (such as in a wiki and in in-repository README files) will tend to result in them getting out of sync, and more than likely one of those will rot.

Given that the canonical source of the documentation should only be in one place, in the code repository itself seems ideal.

  • Keeping them somewhere other than the code repository implies no documentation in the repository other than a URL to that other location. That leaves a user with a checkout with no documentation in offline situations. Also if you have an old checkout of the code the URL may lead nowhere at all. With the in-repository model, if you have a checkout of the repository you always have the relevant documentation right there.

  • Documentation versions are kept synchronized with code versions.

    • A feature branch that changes behavior can also update the documentation. The behavior changes and documentation changes can be merged atomically.

    • If you have an old checkout or an archive tarball of the code, you also have the version of the documentation that applies to that exact version.

  • In-repository documentation sources can be edited with external editors, rather than browser text windows. (This is also possible with some alternative ways of managing documentation, but not currently in Allura's wiki tool)

In-Repository Documentation with SourceForge's Allura Platform

While there are a number of tools for publishing a git repository of Markdown files as a web site, to my knowledge they are intended for use with a dedicated repository, and not with a repository that primarily holds something else (code) and has the documentation sprinkled throughout as markdown files. It might be possible to use existing tools to support this use-case though, and in particular I've managed to use SourceForge's Allura platform's git-repository web-view-tool for this purpose.

In-repository documentation in the XMHF project

The documentation in the XMHF is in markdown files in the code repository itself. Documentation is placed in the file-system near the relevant component, with a top-level README.md for the whole repository and for each component.

 COPYING.md
 README.md
 libbaremetal/
  README.md
 lockdown/
  README.md
 tee-cred/
  README.md
 tee-sdk/
  README.md
 trustvisor/
  doc/
   building-trustvisor.md
   installing-trustvisor.md
   nv-storage.md
  README.md
 xmhf/
     doc/
      amt-serial-over-lan.md
      building-xmhf.md
      configuring-grub.md
      custom-linux-kernels.md
      debugging-xmhf.md
      hardware-requirements.md
      installing-xmhf.md
     README.md

The documentation is viewable in html format through SourceForge's web view of the xmhf repository. The html conversion is done transparently by SourceForge's Allura platform.

Suggested improvements

The usability of this technique could be improved a lot with some small changes to the Allura platform.

Shortcut syntax for relative links

The vanilla Markdown syntax for title-less links is:

[Text](URL)

Within the repository, linking to other files within the repository is largely redundant. It would be nice to support the abbreviated

[path/to/header.h] is a header file specifying...

as a shortcut for:

[path/to/header.h](path/to/header.h) is a header file specifying...

I've filed ticket #4472 requesting that extension.

It would be even nicer if the platform indexed the locations of other markdown files within the repository, allowing for a similar syntax as "artifact links" in the wiki. i.e., it would be nice to allow:

[Installing XMHF]

as a shortcut for:

[Installing XMHF](xmhf/doc/installing-xmhf.md)

Support for linking to most recent version of a file

There is currently no permanent link that always points to the most recent version of a file in a repository. For example, suppose I want to a link to installing-xmhf.md. I can link to the current most-recent version of it as follows: https://sourceforge.net/p/xmhf/xmhf/ci/515d200b1914731871ee312a0bd6e8b9fc412100/tree/xmhf/doc/installing-xmhf.md. However, after that document is updated, the link will still point to the exact same (now deprecated) version of the file.

It would be better if I could link to the most recent with something like: https://sourceforge.net/p/xmhf/xmhf/current/tree/xmhf/doc/installing-xmhf.md

Ticket 4130 requests this feature.

Support for Markdown extensions

The Allura platform extends Markdown to support things like tables and code highlighting... except in the repository viewer. It currently uses a different Markdown processor there that only recognizes vanilla Markdown. Ticket 4474 requests unifying the markdown parsers for consistency.

It would be even nicer if Allura incorporated some of pandoc's markdown extensions, such as definition lists, multi-line tables, footnotes, citations, and internal links.

Other Tools and Platforms

Gitit

I briefly experimented with Gitit. By default it looks in a special sub-directory for markdown files, but it can be configured to use the root directory instead by modifying the repository-path variable. Unfortunately it mandates that all pages end with the suffix .page, rather than recognizing other suffixes like .md. I couldn't find a way to configure this, though presumably it would only require a trivial change to the code.

GitHub

GitHub's repository viewer also renders markdown files. Unfortunately, it appears that creating a relative link from the root README to other files in the repository is impossible, and not likely to be added.

Another possibility I haven't looked into is to use GitHub Pages. That feature publishes Markdown files from a branch named gh-pages, using jekyll. My impression is that the intended usage is for the gh-pages branch to diverge from code branches at the first commit, and not contain the code itself. However, I don't think there's anything to stop one from keeping gh-pages synchronized with master; i.e., having the markdown files mixed with the code.
